docs.snippet: An  article  on Monday about venture capitalists’ interest in food-related start-ups misstated the restaurant experience of Chris Muscarella, a co-founder of the site Kitchensurfing. While he has worked in restaurants, he has not been a che...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about venture capitalists’ interest in food-related start-ups misstated the restaurant experience of Chris Muscarella, a co-founder of the site Kitchensurfing. While he has worked in restaurants, he has not been a chef. The article also referred incorrectly to the investment history of Google Ventures. It has indeed made food-related investments, providing venture capital to Blue Bottle Coffee, a specialty retailer; it is not the case that it has not yet put money into such companies.

headline.main: Corrections

headline.main: Google Glass Picks Up Early Signal: Keep Out
headline.print_headline: Google Glass Picks Up Early Signal: Keep Out

docs.abstract: Google’s wearable computer, most anticipated piece of electronic wizardry since iPad and iPhone, will not go on sale for many months, but resistance is already under way; glasseslike device known as Google Glass, which allows users to access Internet, take photos and film short snippets, has been pre-emptively banned in some places; is prompting questions of whether it will distract drivers, upend relationships and strip people of what little privacy they still have in public.

docs.snippet: During the dot-com boom, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital investment firm, all but minted money, making prescient early investments in Netscape Communications,  Amazon.com  and  Google  and delivering astonishing returns ...
docs.lead_paragraph:
During the dot-com boom, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital investment firm, all but minted money, making prescient early investments in Netscape Communications, Amazon.com and Google and delivering astonishing returns to investors. Along the way, it became a symbol of Silicon Valley.
 
But the firm has hit a rough patch over the last decade, frustrated by unsuccessful forays into clean technology and by a catch-up effort to take later-stage stakes in social media companies.

headline.main: A Humbled Kleiner Perkins Adjusts Its Strategy

headline.seo: Google Glass May Be Hands-Free, But Not Brain-Free
headline.main: Is Google Glass Dangerous?
headline.print_headline: Is Google Glass Dangerous?

docs.abstract: Gray Matter column by psychology Profs Daniel J Simons and Christopher F Chabris highlights experiments that they and others have conducted that raise troubling implications about way in which Google Glass technology could affect people's attention of the world around them.

docs.snippet: Joaquín Almunia, the European Union competition commissioner, said that Google could still face formal charges for violating European competition law....
docs.lead_paragraph: Joaquín Almunia, the European Union competition commissioner, said that Google could still face formal charges for violating European competition law.

headline.main: Europe Warns Google It Could Face Further Concessions
headline.print_headline: Google Is Warned to Adhere to European Antitrust Deal

docs.abstract: European Union competition commissioner Joaquin Almunia warns Google that it might need to make further concessions to settle case concerning its hugely lucrative online search and advertising businesses; says he is still reviewing feedback from companies and organizations involved in antitrust case and market testing is underway to see if proposed remedies adequately address complaints against Google.

docs.snippet: The Transportation Department said that driverless cars should not yet be allowed, except for testing, but noted that some safety features could save lives....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department said that driverless cars should not yet be allowed, except for testing, but noted that some safety features could save lives.

headline.main: Self-Driving Cars for Testing Are Supported by U.S.
headline.print_headline: Self-Driving Cars for Testing Are Supported by U.S.

docs.abstract: Transportation Depart issues formal policy statement on autonomous vehicles, saying driverless cars should not yet be allowed except for testing; also holds that semiautonomous features like lane centering and automatic speed adjustment could save lives; statement comes as companies like Google have made significant technological strides in making cars that drive themselves.

byline.contributor: Claire Cain Miller reported from San Francisco and Matthew L. Wald from Washington. John M. Broder contributed reporting from Washington and Bill Vlasic from Detroit.
byline.original: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER and MATTHEW L. WALD
